description: Back-formation from allotropy, as allo- +‎ -trope, from Ancient Greek ἄλλος (állos, “other”), and τρόπος (trópos, “way, manner”).

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Any form of an element that has a distinctly different molecular structure to another form of the same element. [from 1847]
examples:
Ozone (O3) is an allotrope of oxygen, normally O2
Note: Different structural forms of a compound are isomers.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) An other form, a different shape of a lexical unit.
(philosophy) An alternative shape of a cognitive structure.
